Award.AwardTitle: Placing our Solar System in Context Through the Characterization of Long-Period Exoplanets
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, which is called the Transit Ephemeris Refinement and Monitoring Survey (TERMS), will determine improved orbital information in order to provide more accurate transit windows for intermediate-to-long-period planets with subsequent observational follow-up at the predicted transit times. High precision radial-velocity and photometric measurements of the newly identified exoplanets will be used to determine planetary composition and test models of planetary formation. The PI and his collaborators will focus on long-period (P > 20 days) planets, which have been excluded from most other studies due to a bias toward shorter periods (due to observational constraints).

Transiting planets have orbital inclinations which cause them to appear to pass in front of their host star, and thus temporarily block some of the starlight. Transits provide special opportunities to measure the relative radii and masses of planets compared to the host star, which is useful to determining planetary density and composition. This project will result in measurements of a group of exoplanets for which very little is known ? namely, cooler and less-massive planets that are farther from their host star. This will provide an important balance to exoplanet databases, which are currently heavy with ?hot Jupiters,? which to now have been easier to observe, and provide more opportunities to observe planets which are closer to Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system. Additionally, the ephemeris data and light-curves provided will be useful to other astronomers in the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The TERMS project has been enormously successful and continues to monitor and characterize exoplanetary systems. We have accumulated an enormous data resource that presents a large opportunity for scientific exploitation.

A primary focus of the TERMS project is to produce significantly
improved orbits of known exoplanets. Various resources available to the TERMS members were utlized to acquire new radial velocity measurements, including Keck, Lick, and the HET. In addition, TERMS has worked with a variety of other groups to obtain data for southern targets. These facilities
include CORALIE, HARPS, PARAS, and instrumentation available to the
Anglo-Australia Planet Search (AAPS) team. Postdoc Natalie Hinkel developed software to automatically send nightly/weekly emails to TERMS members to notify observers of upcoming significant events in planetary orbits (such as transits or periastron passage) for observational planning.

The project funds were partially used for travel to observing runs at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory (CTIO) where much of the photometric data were acquired. We also made use of the unprecedented photometric baseline offered by the APTs located at the Fairborn Observatory in southern Arizona, operated by collaborator Greg Henry. Included in our long-term observing program are 150 stars that are regularly observed TERMS targets. Because of the long lifetime of the APTs, tens of thousands of photometric observations are awaiting refinement and characterization in order to better understand those nearby individual planetary systems.

The TERMS project has contributed to 15 refereed publications studying over 18 targets. Several more papers are currently with the referees of high-impact journals. All TERMS data, with revised fits for each planet, have been made available to the astronomical community as the papers have been published.

The TERMS project has successfully trained undergraduate/graduate students and postdocs, as evidenced by the publications of Genady Pilyavsky from PSU (Pilyavsky et al. 2011), Xuesong Wang from PSU (Wang et al. 2012) and Diana Dragomir from UBC (Dragomir et al. 2011, 2012). Most of the funds from this proposal were used to hire Natalie Hinkel who led several aspects of the TERMS project, including building and maintaining database infrastructure, software development, and observing proposals, as well as the publication of a number of targets (e.g., Hinkel et al. 2015). We expect to train more students at various levels as the TERMS project continues to move forward.

The accurate orbits that have been measured by TERMS and provided to the community are already being used as a target selection resource for current and upcoming space missions, such as K2, the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS), and the CHaracterizing ExOPlanet Satellite (CHEOPS).
